items.title: Frank had 'unique' Man Utd & Chelsea talks on same day
items.summary: Tottenham manager Thomas Frank had talks with both Chelsea and Manchester United on the same day last year.

items.title: Google plans to invest $40 billion towards building data centers in Texas
items.summary: Google is getting ready to spend $40 billion to increase its data center footprint in Texas. In an announcement posted on its website, Google said it's planning to build more infrastructure for its cloud and artificial intelligence operations in the state. The plans call for three new data centers,â€¦

items.title: Sky Sports axes 'sexist' TikTok channel Halo after three days
items.summary: The female-focused TikTok channel was dubbed "patronising" and "sexist" by social media users.

items.title: England level series with win over New Zealand
items.summary: England beat New Zealand 61-58 in a breathless second Test to level the three-match series.

items.title: Italy fighting to avoid another 'apocalyptic' World Cup failure
items.summary: Four-time winners Italy are one of the most successful nations in World Cup history - but are in danger of missing the finals for the third successive time.

items.title: Spurs show progress in derby draw against Arsenal
items.summary: Level on points with Arsenal, five wins from nine and the most clean sheets in the Women's Super League this season - Tottenham are in a good place.

items.title: The Meta Quest 3S VR headset drops to a record-low price for Black Friday
items.summary: Meta's entry-level VR headset, the Quest 3S, is down to an even more budget-friendly price than usual in a deal on Amazon right now. The 128GB Meta Quest 3S is 17 percent off in an early Black Friday deal, bringing it to a record-low price of $250. It normally goes for $300. With the purchase, you â€¦

items.title: Who is I'm a Celebrity's Alex Scott?
items.summary: Our Ask Me Anything Team look at the career of former Lioness and Arsenal player turned I'm A Celebrity Contestant Alex Scott.

items.title: Kumagai scores twice to give London City win over Aston Villa
items.summary: Saki Kumagai scores two headers as London City Lionesses secure their fifth win in the WSL with a 3-1 defeat over Aston Villa .

items.title: Chelsea set new WSL unbeaten record in draw at Liverpool
items.summary: Women's Super League title holders Chelsea drop points for just the third time this season after a 1-1 draw against Liverpool. Women's Super League title holders Chelsea drop points for just the third time this season after a 1-1 draw against Liverpool.

items.title: The Mac Pro could be the latest addition to Apple's product purgatory
items.summary: The wait for a new Mac Pro may take a lot longer, according to the latest Power On newsletter. Bloomberg's Mark Gurman reported that the Mac Pro has an uncertain future within Apple's desktop strategy and isn't likely to see a refresh in 2026. According to Gurman, Apple is no longer working on the â€¦

items.title: Littler becomes world number one with semi-final win
items.summary: Luke Littler will become world number one for the first time after booking his place in the Grand Slam of Darts final in Wolverhampton.

items.title: From unknown teen to world number one - Littler's rise in his own words
items.summary: Darts' new world number one Luke Littler talks BBC Sport through some of the most iconic pictures and moments from his career so far.

items.title: Patten's partners make it dream week for him at ATP Finals
items.summary: Great Britain's Henry Patten completes a life-changing visit to Turin by becoming an ATP Finals champion for the first time - a week after proposing to his girlfriend in the city.

What was once a one-day shopping sprint has turned into a month-long marathon, with retailers rolling out discounts week after week. Thanks to this, it can be easy to get deal fatigue after a while â€” but no one wants to miss out on a good discouâ€¦

items.title: AirPods 4 are on sale for a record-low price in this Black Friday deal
items.summary: Black Friday Apple deals are already trickling in, and one of the best we're tracking is on the AirPods 4. They're down to $85 right now, which is a new record low. While these buds don't provide active noise cancellation, they're still a great option for those who want all of the conveniences of aâ€¦

items.title: 'I have never seen England on a charge like this'
items.summary: In his latest BBC Sport column, World Cup winner Matt Dawson discusses England's comeback against New Zealand, Ollie Lawrence's skillset and Henry Pollock's energy.

items.title: McIlroy clinches seventh overall title, as Fitzpatrick wins in Dubai
items.summary: An emotional Rory McIlroy pays tribute to Seve Ballesteros after eclipsing the Spaniard by clinching his seventh Race to Dubai title, despite being beaten to the DP World Tour Championship by Matt Fitzpatrick.

items.title: McIlroy clinches seventh overall title, as Fitzpatrick wins in Dubai

items.title: This hack can get you one year of Peacock for $49 before Black Friday
items.summary: Walmart is offering its Walmart+ subscription at half off for new sign-ups, and it includes a choice of either Peacock Premium or Paramount+ Essential. The deal for new subscribers is just $49 for the first year, marked down from $98. The real value is in selecting Peacock Premium, which would normâ€¦

items.title: The evolution of rationality: How chimps process conflicting evidence
items.summary: Chimps can take in new evidence, evaluate its strength, and change their minds.
items.body: When Aristotle claimed that humans differ from other animals because they have the ability to be rational, he understood rational to mean that we could form our views and beliefs based on evidence, and that we could reconsider that evidence. â€œYou knowâ€”ask ourselves if we should really believe that based on the evidence weâ€™ve got,â€ says Jan M. Engelmann, an evolutionary anthropologist at the University of California, Berkeley. Engelmann says that from the beginning of the Western intellectual tradition, people thought that only humans are rational. So, he designed a study to see if rationality shows up in chimpanzees. It turned out that theyâ€™re almost as rational as we are. Food puzzles â€œThere was quite a bit of research showing that chimpanzees can form their beliefs in response to evidence,â€ Engelmann says. The experiments usually involved chimpanzees deciding which of the two boxes contained a snack. When the researchers shook both boxes and there was a rattling sound coming from one of them, the chimps almost always chose the box where the rattling came from. Read full article Comments

items.title: Wyoming dinosaur mummies give us a new view of duck-billed species
items.summary: Exquisitely preserved fossils come from a single site in Wyoming.
items.body: Edmontosaurus annectens , a large herbivore duck-billed dinosaur that lived toward the end of the Cretaceous period, was discovered back in 1908 in east-central Wyoming by C.H. Sternberg, a fossil collector. The skeleton, later housed at the American Museum of Natural History in New York and nicknamed the â€œAMNH mummy,â€ was covered by scaly skin imprinted in the surrounding sediment that gave us the first approximate idea of what the animal looked like. More than a century later, a team of paleontologists led by Paul C. Sereno, a professor of organismal biology at the University of Chicago, got back to the same exact place where Sternberg dug up the first Edmontosaurus specimen. The researchers found two more Edmontosaurus mummies with all fleshy external anatomy imprinted in a sub-millimeter layer of clay. For the first time, we uncovered an accurate image of what Edmontosaurus really looked like, down to the tiniest details, like the size of its scales and the arrangement of spikes on its tail. And we were in for at least a few surprises. Evolving images Our view of Edmontosaurus changed over time, even before Serenoâ€™s study. The initial drawing of Edmontosaurus was made in 1909 â€¦

items.title: US may owe $1 trillion in refunds if SCOTUS cancels Trump tariffs
items.summary: Tech industry primed for big refunds if SCOTUS rules against Trump tariffs.
items.body: If Donald Trump loses his Supreme Court fight over tariffs, the US may be forced to return â€œtens of billions of dollars to companies that have paid import fees this year, plus interest,â€ The Atlantic reported . And the longer the verdict is delayed, the higher the refunds could go, possibly even hitting $1 trillion. For tech companies both large and small, the stakes are particularly high. A Trump defeat would not just mean clawing back any duties paid on imports to the US that companies otherwise can use to invest in their competitiveness. But, more critically in the long term, it would also end tariff shocks that, as economics lecturer Matthew Allen emphasized in a report for The Conversation, risked harming â€œinnovation itselfâ€ by destabilizing global partnerships and diverse supply chains in â€œtech-intensive, IP-led sectors like semiconductors and software.â€ Currently, the Supreme Court is weighing two cases that argue that the US president does not have unilateral authority to impose tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). Defending his regime of so-called â€œreciprocal tariffs,â€ Trump argued these taxes were necessary to correct the â€œemergencyâ€ of â€¦

items.title: The twin probes just launched toward Mars have an Easter egg on board
items.summary: "Blue" and "Gold" are expected to arrive at Mars in September 2027.
items.body: The first multi-spacecraft science mission to launch to Mars is now on its way, and catching a ride on the twin probes are the first kiwis to fly to the red planet. NASAâ€™s ESCAPADE (Escape and Plasma Acceleration and Dynamics Explorers) mission lifted off on a 22-month trip to Mars on Thursday aboard a New Glenn rocket . Once there, the identical satellites will enter Martian orbit to study in real time how space weather affects the planetâ€™s hybrid magnetosphere and how the interaction drove Mars to lose its once-dense atmosphere. Led by the Space Sciences Laboratory at the University of California, Berkeleyâ€”the two spacecraft are named â€œBlueâ€ and â€œGoldâ€ after the schoolâ€™s colorsâ€”the ESCAPADE probes are the first Mars-bound vehicles to be designed, built, and tested by Rocket Lab, the end-to-end space company headquartered in California but founded in New Zealand. Read full article Comments

Reports estimate that Disney is losing $4.3 million per day during the blackout, you you would thiâ€¦

items.title: I feel part of a big football nation - Bellamy
items.summary: Wales boss Craig Bellamy says he feels part of a big football nation now as his side battle to finish second in their World Cup qualifying group.

items.title: As shutdown ends, dubious CDC panel gets back to dismantling vaccine schedule
items.summary: Pediatricians are calling for members to be replaced and all their decisions reversed.
items.body: With the government reopening, the dubious panel of vaccine advisors selected by anti-vaccine Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy is wasting no time getting back to dismantling the federal childhood vaccine schedule. A meeting that was scheduled for October but put on hold during the shutdown has already been rescheduled for December 4 and 5. A Federal Register notice Thursday said that the meeting will â€œinclude discussions on vaccine safety, the childhood and adolescent immunization schedule, and hepatitis B vaccines.â€ The announcement was light on information beyond that but indicated that there would be a vote on hepatitis B vaccines. The panelâ€”the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) for the Centers for Disease Control and Preventionâ€”is typically composed of preeminent, extensively vetted vaccine experts. But, in June, Kennedy summarily fired all 17 experts on the panel and installed 12 new members , almost all of whom are questionably qualified and espouse anti-vaccine views. Read full article Comments

items.title: How two Nissan Leafs help make a regional airport more resilient
items.summary: We've seen schoolbuses and big pickups do V2G; how about a smaller car?
items.body: Not everything about the future sucks. Like electric cars. Sure, thereâ€™s one thing that dinosaur-burners do betterâ€”short refueling stopsâ€”but even the least efficient EV is still multiple times better than its gas equivalent. So much better in fact that it offsets all the extra energy needed to make the battery within a year or two. Theyâ€™re quieter, and easy to drive. And in a pinch, they can power your house from the garage. Or how about an airport? OK, weâ€™re not talking about a major international airport (although I really need to talk to someone at Dulles International Airport about my idea to electrify those Space 1999-esque mobile lounges at some point). But up in Humboldt County, California, thereâ€™s a microgrid at the Redwood Coast Airport that has now integrated bidirectional charging, and a pair of Nissan Leaf EVs, into its operation. The microgrid has been operating since 2021 with a 2.2 MW solar array, 8.9 MWh of battery storage, and a 300 KW net-metered solar system. It can feed excess power back into PG&Eâ€™s local grid and draw power from the same, but in an outage, the microgrid can keep the airport up and operational. Read full article Comments

items.title: â€œHow about noâ€: FCC boss Brendan Carr says he wonâ€™t end news distortion probes
items.summary: Carr rejects criticism from four former FCC chairs, including three Republicans.
items.body: Federal Communications Commission Chairman Brendan Carr says he wonâ€™t scrap the agencyâ€™s controversial news distortion policy despite calls from a bipartisan group of former FCC chairs and commissioners. â€œHow about no,â€ Carr wrote in an X post in response to the petition from former FCC leaders. â€œOn my watch, the FCC will continue to hold broadcasters accountable to their public interest obligations.â€ The petition filed yesterday by former FCC chairs and commissioners asked the FCC to repeal its 1960s-era news distortion policy, which Carr has repeatedly invoked in threats to revoke broadcast licenses. In the recent Jimmy Kimmel controversy, Carr said that ABC affiliates could have licenses revoked for news distortion if they kept the comedian on the air. Read full article Comments

items.title: Whatâ€™s it like to compete in the longest US off-road rally with no GPS?
items.summary: Hydrogen and solar power the rally infrastructure, but navigation is low-tech.
items.body: Iâ€™ve been involved with the Rebelle Rally since its inception in 2016, either as a competitor or live show host, and over the past 10 years, Iâ€™ve seen it evolve from a scrappy rally with big dreams to the world-class event that it is today. In a nutshell, the Rebelle Rally is the longest competitive off-road rally in the United States, covering over 2,000 kilometers, and it just happens to be for women. Over eight days, teams of two must plot coordinates on a map, figure out their route, and find multiple checkpointsâ€”both marked and unmarkedâ€”with no GPS, cell phones, or chase crews. It is not a race for speed but rather a rally for navigational accuracy over some of the toughest terrain California and Nevada have to offer. There are two classes: 4Ã—4 with vehicles like the Jeep Wrangler and Ford Bronco and X-Cross for cars like the Honda Passport and BMW X5. Heavy modifications arenâ€™t needed, and many teams compete for the coveted Bone Stock award. For this 10th anniversary, I got back behind the wheel of a 2025 Subaru Crosstrek Wilderness as a driver, with Kendra Miller as my navigator, to defend my multiple podium finishes and stage wins and get reacquainted with the technology, â€¦

items.summary: Greenlandâ€™s melt is expected to slow the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, but research suggests a collapse of the West Antarctic ice sheet could in some cases prevent it from shutting down

items.title: Three astronauts are stuck on Chinaâ€™s space station without a safe ride home
items.summary: "This does not meet the release conditions for a safe manned return."
items.body: Wrapping up 204 days in orbit, three Chinese astronauts flew back to Earth aboard a Shenzhou spacecraft Friday, leaving three crewmates behind on the Tiangong space station with a busted lifeboat. Commander Chen Dong, concluding his third trip to space, and rookie crewmates Chen Zhongrui and Wang Jie touched down inside their spacecraft at the Dongfeng landing zone at 1:29 am EST (06:29 UTC) Friday. The parachute-assisted landing occurred in the mid-afternoon at the return zone, located in the remote Gobi Desert of northwestern China. Chinese space officials upended operations on the countryâ€™s Tiangong space lab last week after astronauts found damage to one of two Shenzhou return capsules docked at the station. The China Manned Space Agency, run by the countryâ€™s military, announced changes to the space stationâ€™s flight plan November 4, the day before three crew members were supposed to depart and fly home. Read full article Comments

items.title: Forget AGIâ€”Sam Altman celebrates ChatGPT finally following em dash formatting rules
items.summary: Ongoing struggles with AI model instruction-following show that true human-level AI still a ways off.
items.body: Em dashes have become what many believe to be a telltale sign of AI-generated text over the past few years. The punctuation mark appears frequently in outputs from ChatGPT and other AI chatbots, sometimes to the point where readers believe they can identify AI writing by its overuse aloneâ€”although people can overuse it, too. On Thursday evening, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman posted on X that ChatGPT has started following custom instructions to avoid using em dashes. â€œSmall-but-happy win: If you tell ChatGPT not to use em-dashes in your custom instructions, it finally does what itâ€™s supposed to do!â€ he wrote. The post, which came two days after the release of OpenAIâ€™s new GPT-5.1 AI model, received mixed reactions from users who have struggled for years with getting the chatbot to follow specific formatting preferences. And this â€œsmall winâ€ raises a very big question: If the worldâ€™s most valuable AI company has struggled with controlling something as simple as punctuation use after years of trying, perhaps what people call artificial general intelligence (AGI) is farther off than some in the industry claim . Read full article Comments

items.title: Worldâ€™s oldest RNA extracted from Ice Age woolly mammoth
items.summary: Sequencing an ancient creatureâ€™s RNA opens up a new window into extinct life.
items.body: A young woolly mammoth now known as Yuka was frozen in the Siberian permafrost for about 40,000 years before it was discovered by local tusk hunters in 2010. The hunters soon handed it over to scientists, who were excited to see its exquisite level of preservation, with skin, muscle tissue, and even reddish hair intact. Later research showed that, while full cloning was impossible, Yukaâ€™s DNA was in such good condition that some cell nuclei could even begin limited activity when placed inside mouse eggs. Now, a team has successfully sequenced Yukaâ€™s RNAâ€”a feat many researchers once thought impossible. Researchers at Stockholm University carefully ground up bits of muscle and other tissue from Yuka and nine other woolly mammoths, then used special chemical treatments to pull out any remaining RNA fragments, which are normally thought to be much too fragile to survive even a few hours after an organism has died. Scientists go to great lengths to extract RNA even from fresh samples, and most previous attempts with very old specimens have either failed or been contaminated. A different view The team used RNA-handling methods adapted for ancient, fragmented molecules. Their scientific â€¦

items.title: Dogs came in a wide range of sizes and shapes long before modern breeds
items.summary: Life with humans changed dogs in some dramatic ways, and it didn't take long.
items.body: Our best friends come in a fantastic array of shapes and sizes; a Borzoi looks nothing like a Boston terrier, except for a certain fundamental, ineffable (except to taxonomists) doggyness about them. And itâ€™s been that way almost from the beginning. A recent study of dog and wolf skulls from the last 50,000 years found that dogs living just after the last Ice Age were already about half as varied in their shape and size as modern dogs. â€œ Shaped like a friendâ€ means a lot of different things Biologist and archaeologist Allowen Evin, of CNRS, and her colleagues compared the size and shape of 643 skulls from dogs and wolves: 158 from modern dogs, 86 from modern wolves, and 391 from archaeological sites around the world spanning the last 50,000 years. By comparing the locations and sizes of certain skeletal landmarks, such as bony protrusions where muscles attached, the researchers could quantify how different one skull was from another. That suggested a few things about how dogs, or at least the shapes of their heads, have evolved over time. The teamâ€™s results suggest that dogs that lived during the Mesolithic (before settled farming life came into fashion in the Middle East) and theâ€¦

items.title: Scientist pleaded guilty to smuggling Fusarium graminearum into US. But what is it?
items.summary: Early warning system being developed by universities may slow the plant pathogen.
items.body: A Chinese plant scientist at the University of Michigan, who drew national attention in June 2025 when she was arrested and accused along with another Chinese scientist of smuggling a crop-damaging fungus into the US, pleaded guilty on November 12, 2025, to charges of smuggling and making false statements to the FBI. Under her plea agreement, Yunqing Jian, 33, was sentenced to time served and expected to be deported . Her arrest put a spotlight on Fusarium graminearum , a harmful pathogen. But while its risk to grains such as wheat, corn, and rice can be alarming, Fusarium isnâ€™t new to American farmers. The US Department of Agriculture estimates it costs wheat and barley farmers more than $1 billion a year . Tom Allen , an extension and research professor of plant pathology at Mississippi State University, explains what Fusarium graminearum is and isnâ€™t. Read full article Comments

items.title: Years later, Arkaneâ€™s Dishonored is still a modern stealth classic
items.summary: Steam punk magical-realist world-building at its finest.
items.body: Back in 2012, Dishonored earned the first Game of the Year honor of my tenure at Ars Technica. Looking back on the game some 13 years later, Arkaneâ€™s well-constructed world of steam punk magical realism earns its place as a modern classic. The game does a great job of drawing you into that world immediately, with a memorable opening sequence that sees you framed for the on-screen murder of the empress youâ€™ve been sworn to protect. The scene does a great job establishing the emotional stakes of the coming missions while also throwing you into the deep end of the political infighting that has consumed a besieged, plague-beset kingdom. A Victorian steam punk world you can lose yourself in. Credit: Arkane Studios Those stakes, and a battle against a real feeling of injustice, drive the plot through some admittedly predictable beats as Dishonored continues through a set of sneak-and-assassinate missions. But itâ€™s hard to care about that predictability when even minor side characters on both sides of the conflict quickly develop from stereotypes to engaging, fleshed-out characters. Read full article Comments

items.title: Blue Originâ€™s New Glenn rocket came back home after taking aim at Mars
items.summary: "Never before in history has a booster this large nailed the landing on the second try."
items.body: The rocket company founded a quarter-century ago by billionaire Jeff Bezos made history Thursday with the pinpoint landing of an 18-story-tall rocket on a floating platform in the Atlantic Ocean. The on-target touchdown came nine minutes after the New Glenn rocket, built and operated by Bezosâ€™ company Blue Origin, lifted off from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Florida, at 3:55 pm EST (20:55 UTC). The launch was delayed from Sunday, first due to poor weather at the launch site in Florida, then by a solar storm that sent hazardous radiation toward Earth earlier this week. â€œWe achieved full mission success today, and I am so proud of the team,â€ said Dave Limp, CEO of Blue Origin. â€œIt turns out Never Tell Me The Odds (Blue Originâ€™s nickname for the first stage) had perfect oddsâ€”never before in history has a booster this large nailed the landing on the second try. This is just the beginning as we rapidly scale our flight cadence and continue delivering for our customers.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Rocket Report: Blue Originâ€™s stunning success; vive le Baguette One!
items.summary: "If NASA wants to go quicker, we would move heaven and Earth."
items.body: Welcome to Edition 8.19 of the Rocket Report! Thursday was a monumental day in launch history with Blue Originâ€™s New Glenn rocket not just taking off successfully, but with the first stage masterfully returning to the surface of the ocean, hovering near the Jacklyn drone ship, and then making a landing in the center of the barge. It was fantastic to watch and cements our new reality of reusable rockets. The future of space access is very bright indeed. As always, we welcome reader submissions , and if you donâ€™t want to miss an issue, please subscribe using the box below (the form will not appear on AMP-enabled versions of the site). Each report will include information on small-, medium-, and heavy-lift rockets as well as a quick look ahead at the next three launches on the calendar. Private Chinese rocket fails . Galactic Energyâ€™s solid-fuel Ceres-1 rocket lifted off from Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center in northwest China on Sunday, carrying three satellites toward low-Earth orbit. The rocketâ€™s first three stages performed well, according to media reports, but its fourth and final stage shut down too early, leading to the loss of all three payloads, Space.com reports . Read full â€¦

items.title: US spy satellites built by SpaceX send signals in the â€œwrong directionâ€
items.summary: It seems US didn't coordinate Starshield's unusual spectrum use with other countries.
items.body: About 170 Starshield satellites built by SpaceX for the US governmentâ€™s National Reconnaissance Office (NRO) have been sending signals in the wrong direction, a satellite researcher found. The SpaceX-built spy satellites are helping the NRO greatly expand its satellite surveillance capabilities , but the purpose of these signals is unknown. The signals are sent from space to Earth in a frequency band thatâ€™s allocated internationally for Earth-to-space and space-to-space transmissions. There have been no public complaints of interference caused by the surprising Starshield emissions. But the researcher who found them says they highlight a troubling lack of transparency in how the US government manages the use of spectrum and a failure to coordinate spectrum usage with other countries. Read full article Comments

items.title: Harder & Carmona star in Champions League best goals
items.summary: Watch the best goals from the latest round of fixtures from the Women's Champions League, including Olga Carmona's screamer for Paris St-Germain and Pernille Harder's equaliser against Arsenal.

items.title: This flu season looks grim as H3N2 emerges with mutations
items.summary: The UK is facing one of the worst flu seasons in historyâ€”and the US is next.
items.body: Health officials in the United Kingdom are warning that this yearâ€™s flu season for the Northern Hemisphere is looking like it will be particularly roughâ€”and the US is not prepared. The bleak outlook is driven by a new strain of H3N2, which emerged over the summer (at the end of the Southern Hemisphereâ€™s season) sporting several mutations. Those changes are not enough to spark the direst of circumstancesâ€”a deadly pandemicâ€”but they could help the virus dodge immune responses, resulting in an outsize number of severe illnesses that could put a significant strain on hospitals and clinics. In the UK, the virus has taken off. The regionâ€™s flu season has started around five weeks earlier than normal and is making a swift ascent. Read full article Comments

items.title: A 'circus' or sign of the times - should Joshua take Paul fight?
items.summary: BBC Sport assesses whether Anthony Joshua's prospective fight with YouTuber Jake Paul would be a good or bad idea.

items.title: Google claims win for everyone as text scammers lost their cloud server
items.summary: Text scam ringleader warned operations were disrupted on Telegram, Google says.
items.body: The day after Google filed a lawsuit to end text scams primarily targeting Americans, the criminal network behind the phishing scams was â€œdisrupted,â€ a Google spokesperson told Ars. According to messages that the â€œringleaderâ€ of the so-called â€œLighthouse enterpriseâ€ posted on his Telegram channel, the phishing gangâ€™s cloud server was â€œblocked due to malicious complaints.â€ â€œWe will restore it as soon as possible!â€ the leader posted on the channelâ€”which Googleâ€™s lawsuit noted helps over 2,500 members coordinate phishing attacks that have resulted in losses of â€œover a billion dollars.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Fossil fuel emissions rise again â€“ but China's are levelling off
items.summary: Global emissions from fossil fuels are expected to hit another record high in 2025, but Chinaâ€™s carbon emissions appear to be reaching a peak

items.title: Strongest evidence yet that the Epstein-Barr virus causes lupus
items.summary: Lupus has been linked to the Epstein-Barr virus â€“ which causes glandular fever, or mono â€“ before, but we now have evidence of how it can bring about the autoimmune condition

items.title: The 19th-century maths that can help you deal with horrible coffee
items.summary: Do you need to fairly allocate players to teams, or sort out a pot of badly brewed coffee? Katie Steckles has a mathematical solution

items.title: Breaking Bad showrunner uses sci-fi for smart dive into happiness
items.summary: Vince Gilligan, the showrunner behind Breaking Bad and Better Call Saul, is back, this time using sci-fi to explore a deceptively rich premise about the pursuit of happiness and the notion of utopia, finds Bethan Ackerley

items.title: New Scientist recommends this extreme birdwatching documentary
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: Smart new book takes an axe to the myth of human exceptionalism
items.summary: Christine Webb's provocative and moving book The Arrogant Ape explores our unjustifiable sense of superiority in the living world, laying out the evidence against it, says Elle Hunt

items.title: Is the future of education outside universities?
items.summary: New technologies and academic funding cuts are upending the ways we learn today. Newly enrolled student Annalee Newitz finds some silver linings

items.title: Sperm are selfish â€“ and so are we
items.summary: A new study hammers home how the "survival of the nicest" view makes no sense when it comes to evolution, says Jonathan R. Goodman

items.title: Surprising new biography of Francis Crick unravels the story of DNA
items.summary: Francis Crick's biography is full of surprises as author Matthew Cobb reveals the life and work of the co-discoverer of DNA's structure, finds Michael Le Page

items.title: Kim Kardashian has wrangled an invite to NASA HQ. Can we get one too?
items.summary: Reality TV star Kim Kardashian apparently thinks the 1969 moon landing was fake. If Feedback comes up with an equally outlandish conspiracy theory, maybe we can also get a guided tour of NASA

items.title: Remarkable robot images provide a vision of the future
items.summary: These photographs of humanoid robots by Henrik Spohler are part of his project Tomorrow Is the Question

items.title: Sex could help wounds heal faster by reducing stress
items.summary: Mild wounds healed faster if people took a spray containing the "love hormone" oxytocin and set aside time to praise their partner â€“ but they cleared up even quicker if these individuals were also intimate with their other half

items.title: Huge cloud of plasma belched out by star 130 light years away
items.summary: A coronal mass ejection from a distant star has been confirmed for the first time, raising questions about how such events could impact exoplanet habitability

items.title: Is a deadly asteroid about to hit Earth? Meet the man who can tell you
items.summary: When an asteroid threatens Earth, astronomers use a rating called the Torino scale to communicate the risk. Richard Binzel, who invented the scale, tells New Scientist about his 50-year career in planetary defence

items.title: Chemical computer can recognise patterns and perform multiple tasks
items.summary: Previous attempts at building a chemical computer have been too simple, too rigid or too hard to scale, but an approach based on a network of reactions can perform multiple tasks without having to be reconfigured

items.title: Cradle of humanity is still revealing new insights about our origins
items.summary: The Omo-Turkana basin in Africa is home to a treasure trove of ancient human fossils and tools that span 300,000 years â€“ today it is still yielding new discoveries about our species

items.title: At-home hypnosis relieves menopausal hot flushes
items.summary: Hot flushes could be relieved by listening to recordings that induce hypnosis from home, rather than having to venture to a clinic

items.title: Women have supercharged immune systems and we now know why
items.summary: Being born with two X chromosomes brings a host of health benefits, and recognising this could lead to personalised medical treatments for men and women

items.title: Static electricity can remove frost from windows using little energy
items.summary: High-voltage copper plates can remove up to three-quarters of frost from a surface, while using much less energy than conventional heating

items.title: Odds of asteroid 2024 YR4 hitting the moon may rise to 30 per cent
items.summary: In February, the James Webb Space Telescope will briefly be able to observe asteroid 2024 YR4, which currently has a 4 per cent chance of hitting the moon in 2032. Depending on what it sees, the odds of collision could drastically increase

items.title: James Watson, co-discoverer of DNAâ€™s double helix, has died aged 97
items.summary: As one of the most influential scientists of the 20th century, James Watson pioneered the field of genetics and left behind a complicated legacy

items.title: Enceladusâ€™s ocean may be even better for life than we realised
items.summary: The buried ocean on Saturnâ€™s moon Enceladus seems to be stable across extremely long periods of time, making it an even more promising place to hunt for life

items.title: Having children plays a complicated role in the rate we age
items.summary: The effort of reproducing may divert energy away from repairing DNA or fighting illness, which could drive ageing, but a new study suggests that is only the case when environmental conditions are tough

items.title: A distant galaxy is being strangled by the cosmic web
items.summary: A dwarf galaxy 100 million light years away is being stripped of its crucial star-forming gas, and it seems that the cosmic web is siphoning off this gas as the galaxy passes through

items.title: We may never figure out where interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS came from
items.summary: The surface of comet 3I/ATLAS may have been so radically altered by cosmic rays that deducing its home star system would be impossible

items.title: A three-legged lion has learned to hunt in a completely unexpected way
items.summary: Jacob, an 11-year-old lion, has defied expectations by surviving for years after losing a leg â€“ now we know his success is down to an innovative hunting strategy

items.title: Digital map lets you explore the Roman Empire's vast road network
items.summary: Archaeologists have compiled the most detailed map yet of roads throughout the Roman Empire in AD 150, totalling almost 300,000 kilometres in length

items.title: Grafting trick could let us gene-edit a huge variety of plants
items.summary: Many plants including cocoa, coffee and avocado cannot be gene-edited but a technique involving grafting could change that, opening the door to more productive and nutritious varieties

items.title: Boa: A standard-conforming embeddable JavaScript engine written in Rust
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Is the expansion of the universe slowing down?
items.summary: It is widely accepted that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate, but now researchers say our measurements of the mysterious force driving that may be wrong and that the universe began to slow 1.5 billion years ago â€“ yet other scientists disagree

items.title: New quantum computer is on the path to unravelling superconductivity
items.summary: Using the Helios-1 quantum computer, researchers have used a record-breaking number of error-proof qubits to run the first and biggest quantum simulation of a model for perfect conductivity

items.title: Here's how to spot the Leonid meteor shower this month
items.summary: A new moon on 20 November means there is a great opportunity to enjoy the Leonid meteor shower this year, says Abigail Beall. Just make sure to get warm and comfy first

items.title: New Scientist recommends the cult film Hackers â€“ 30 years late
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: New book tells compelling tale of the fight to save the Siberian tiger
items.summary: The battle to save the magnificent but endangered Amur tiger detailed in Jonathan Slaght's Tigers Between Empires is an inspiring look at what collaboration across borders can achieve, finds Adam Weymouth

items.title: Is a robot programmed to prank you annoying? Yes
items.summary: Feedback discovers a robot that can mimic Turkish ice cream vendors, who are known for playing tricks on their customers. Researchers concluded that customers, perhaps predictably, don't trust it

items.title: Human minds abhor uncertainty. This is a problem for liberal democracy
items.summary: Neurologically, the flexibility of the future promised by liberal democracy can be a challenge because it brings with it uncertainty. But there are solutions, say Florence Gaub and Liya Yu

items.title: This book is a great insight into the new science of microchimerism
items.summary: Lise BarnÃ©oud's Hidden Guests shows how this fascinating new field brings with it profound implications for medicine, and even what it means to be human, finds Helen Thomson

items.title: Deep-space sci-fi novel is delightful, profound and not to be missed
items.summary: A planet is about to be destroyed by the collapse of a binary star system in Slow Gods, Claire Northâ€™s first venture into classic science fiction. Read it! says Emily H. Wilson

items.title: Fourier Transforms
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Lumpy â€˜caterpillar wormholesâ€™ may connect entangled black holes
items.summary: A mathematical model suggests that when a pair of black holes gets quantum entangled, this can give rise to a lumpy space-time tunnel between them

items.title: What weâ€™re learning about consciousness from master meditatorsâ€™ brains
items.summary: Neuroscientist Matthew Sacchet is revealing how mastering meditation can not only enable transcendental states of bliss, but also reshape how we experience pain and emotion

items.title: Ancient DNA may rewrite the story of Iceland's earliest settlers
items.summary: Biochemical evidence suggests Norse people settled in Iceland almost 70 years before the accepted arrival date of the 870s, and didn't chop down the island's forests

items.title: COP30: Whatâ€™s on the agenda at the BelÃ©m climate summit
items.summary: Initiatives on the table at COP30 aim to evaluate which countries are most vulnerable, support efforts to clean up industries and pay for the protection of tropical forests

items.title: Covid raises risk of heart issues in children more than vaccination
items.summary: Getting covid-19 for the first time slightly increased the risk of heart inflammation, blood clots and bleeding disorders among children, whereas being vaccinated against the virus was much safer and sometimes protective

items.title: Measuring the doppler shift of WWVB during a flight
items.summary: Comments

items.title: The fascinating story of the ultimate cosmic law
items.summary: How do we know the speed of light â€“ and why does it have a speed limit at all? Leah Crane explores the history of one of the most important numbers in the universe

items.title: We're closing in on how genetics may influence your PCOS risk
items.summary: In the largest genetic analysis of polycystic ovary syndrome to date, scientists have identified new variants linked to the condition, which could help us treat it more effectively

items.title: How preppers plan to save us if the whole internet collapses
items.summary: Recent outages have revealed how vulnerable the internet is, but there seems to be no official plan in the event of a catastrophic failure. Meet the team of hackers who are ready to jump into action

items.title: COP30: Can Brazil summit get climate negotiations back on track?
items.summary: Expectations are low for the UN climate conference in BelÃ©m, Brazil, but the hostâ€™s pragmatic approach could help make progress on implementation

items.title: Advanced quantum network could be a prototype for the quantum internet
items.summary: Building a working quantum internet would require overcoming a host of technical challenges, but researchers who have built one of the most advanced quantum networks to date say they think it is possible

items.title: Brightest black hole flare ever caused by huge star being ripped apart
items.summary: A distant black hole has been caught releasing the brightest flare ever, which is the result of it ripping apart and devouring an enormous star

items.title: Cavities could be prevented by a gel that restores tooth enamel
items.summary: Enamel does not naturally regenerate, which can lead to painful cavities, but a gel that harnesses some of the properties of saliva could restore the hard, shiny layer to teeth

items.title: Walking 3000 steps a day seems to slow Alzheimer's-related decline
items.summary: Alzheimer's-related cognitive decline could be slowed by taking as few as 3000 steps a day, possibly due to the effects of regular exercise on brain health

items.title: Diamonds and Lasers: Thermal Management for Chips
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Antarctic glacier's alarming retreat is the fastest ever seen
items.summary: Hektoria glacier on the Antarctic Peninsula retreated 25 kilometres in just 15 months. Its rapid melt could have implications for other glaciers and the rate of sea level rise

items.title: Does the family tree of ancient humans need a drastic rewrite?
items.summary: Anthropologist Christopher Bae has recently suggested we add two new species of ancient human to our family tree. The plans break the conventions for how species should be named â€“ but Bae argues the rules themselves are flawed

items.title: SpaceX's Starlink and other satellites face growing threat from sun
items.summary: There are now over 10,000 satellites in orbit, more than at any point in history, and this growing number is starting to reveal how solar storms could disrupt internet mega constellations like SpaceX's Starlink

items.title: Our bodies are ageing faster than ever. Can we hit the brakes?
items.summary: All over the world people are ageing more rapidly and succumbing to diseases that typically affected the elderly. But there are ways to turn back the clock on your biological age

items.title: We may have found a surprisingly nearby cluster of primordial stars
items.summary: The very first generation of stars, called Population III stars, are mostly expected to be too distant to see directly â€“ but astronomers may have found some for the very first time

items.title: Orcas are ganging up on great white sharks to eat their livers
items.summary: For the first time, video footage has captured orcas in the Gulf of California hunting young great white sharks, using a trick to flip them over, paralise them and get at their energy-rich livers

items.title: Writing a DOS Clone in 2019
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Quantum computers reveal that the wave function is a real thing
items.summary: The uncertainty inherent to quantum mechanics has long left physicists wondering whether the observations we make on the quantum level reflect reality - a new test suggests they do

items.title: Denisovans may have interbred with mysterious group of ancient humans
items.summary: We now have only the second high-quality genome from an ancient Denisovan human, which reveals there were more populations of this species than we thought

items.title: Bulletproof fabric laced with carbon nanotubes is stronger than Kevlar
items.summary: A sheet of fabric that is three times stronger than Kevlar could stop a bullet despite being just 1.8 millimetres thick, thanks to the addition of carbon nanotubes that keep its molecules aligned

items.title: Your flight emissions are way higher than carbon calculators suggest
items.summary: Existing tools that work out the carbon footprint of flights greatly underestimate their warming impact, say the makers of a new calculator

items.title: The gut microbiome may play a role in shaping our personality
items.summary: Rats given a faecal transplant from exuberant toddlers showed more exploratory behaviour, supporting the idea that gut bacteria might affect childrenâ€™s emotional development

items.title: The best new science fiction books of November 2025
items.summary: From Claire Northâ€™s new novel Slow Gods to a 10th anniversary edition of a brilliant Adrian Tchaikovsky book, thereâ€™s lots to watch out for in Novemberâ€™s science fiction

items.title: Our verdict on Our Brains, Our Selves: A mix of praise and misgivings
items.summary: The New Scientist Book Club has various issues with Masud Husain's prize-winning popular science book about neurology

items.title: Book Club: Read an extract from Every Version of You by Grace Chan
items.summary: In this passage from the opening of Grace Chanâ€™s sci-fi novel, the November read for the New Scientist Book Club, we are introduced to her protagonists as they spend time in a virtual utopia which is becoming increasingly tempting in a dying world

items.title: If you could upload your mind to a virtual utopia, would you?
items.summary: Grace Chan, author of Every Version of You, the November read for the New Scientist Book Club, explores the philosophical implications of the choices her characters make

items.title: Boy's body was mummified and turned green by a copper coffin
items.summary: The green mummified remains of a teenager buried in Italy 200 to 400 years ago have given us new insights into the preservative properties of copper

items.title: Sorry, but interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS really is a comet, not aliens
items.summary: Interstellar objects like 3I/ATLAS are exciting, but there is no reason to claim that they are evidence of alien spacecraft â€“ sometimes a comet is just comet, says Robin George Andrews

items.title: Magnetic gel could remove kidney stones more effectively
items.summary: Standard techniques for removing kidney stones often require repeated surgery, but a magnetic gel seems to make the process more efficient

items.title: Cats revealed in all their glory in stunning new photographs
items.summary: Photographer Tim Flach's new book Feline explores the mysterious and irresistible world of cats, from the domesticated to the wild, and why we love them

items.title: Nature documentary shot on Super 8 film is ravishing and unpredictable
items.summary: In Ed Sayers's breathtaking documentary, a global community of film-makers capture the wildlife in their local areas. It's a bold departure from the glossy perspective of traditional nature documentaries, says Simon Ings

items.title: New Scientist recommends Never Let Me Go
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: Owning our own data is the only way to stop enshittifcation
items.summary: The internet is not what it once was, with so many apps and websites mere shadows of themselves. Thankfully, the inventor of the web Tim Berners-Lee, has a fix that we should adopt

items.title: Has life today been enshittified? Cory Doctorow's new book explores
items.summary: Enshittification is a term coined by Cory Doctorow in 2022. In his new book, Doctorow lays out how tech companies have made our lives progressively worse, finds Matthew Sparkes

items.title: 'Most of it is good': Tim Berners-Lee on the state of the web now
items.summary: The man who invented the web is aware of the many issues it faces, from problematic social media use to the rise of unfettered AI. He also has a plan to remedy the situation

items.title: How a surge in ancient plagues 5000 years ago shaped humanity
items.summary: Plague, leprosy, smallpox and other diseases didn't jump from animals to humans when we thought. Ancient DNA is revealing where they come from and how they changed history

items.title: No space, no time, no particles: A radical vision of quantum reality
items.summary: If we admit that quantum numbers are the true essence of reality â€“ not particles, space or time â€“ then a surprising and beautiful new vision of reality opens up to us
